ResponsesInList.Title: how to reset everything in moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: I have made many changes to the moodle cloud before. But in sudden change of plan, I need to restart everything from default settings. I read couple of answers saying how to reset but they did not take me back to the default setting in the dashboard etc. Is it possible to start from scratch without getting another plan.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: how to reset everything in moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ahi, I'm sorry your question was left unanswered for this long. There is no way to do a reset across-the-board for a Moodle site. You can reset a course, each user can reset their dashboard , etc., but you can't really "reset the site". If you are on a paid plan, please contact support (from your portal on https://moodlecloud.com/app/en/portal/ ) and we'll look into it (it can be done server -side, if you really want to get rid of everything to start anew). Mat

ResponsesInList.Title: Domain Verification
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I am having a problem verifying my domain for moodlecloud. I think I have upload the required file and it still cannot verify. Can anyone help?!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Domain Verification
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sean, I'm guessing (correct me if I'm wrong) that you're talking about domain verification google analytics or something like it. If it's for GA, this method won't work, there is no way for Moodle to serve a specific path and uploading files to the Moodle folder on the server is not supported. You can add the javascript code in the "additionalhtmlfooter" (search for that in the admin section), which should do the trick. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud themes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Yohanna, It is not possible to install your own theme on your MoodleCloud site. You are able to change theme to any of the available themes using the theme selector. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud Site Page Not Working
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Katie (and everyone who posted here). I wanted to close this one out by sharing some information about the incident, what we learned, and what plans we have for this to not happen again. 1. Outage We had a failure of a single-point dependency in our US region's infrastructure. At the time of failure, the automatic notification to our on-call engineer also wasn't picked up immediately by our on-call engineer, exacerbating the respond/resolve time. 2. Notification Ideally in a situation like the above, the internal incident notification system will contain a step for automatically notifying an engineering manager when an incident goes unacknowledged by the on-call engineer. This was not configured correctly for management notifications. 3. Communication Ideally in a situation like the above, non-engineering staff are brought into the loop to manage public-facing communications like status.moodlecloud.com and the forums here. Due to the above breakdown in communications, neither of these steps were taken to let the community know about the issues we were having. 4. Outcomes As Product Manager for MoodleCloud, I've taken on 17 discrete changes as a result of this. Some are already in place, others are longer term goals that will make more incremental improvements to how we provide this service to our users. I would like to take this opportunity to apologise for the impact to your services, and I hope that this transparency goes some way to giving you confidence that we're working hard to improve every day here at the MoodleCloud team at Moodle HQ. If you have questions or concerns, please reach out below. I'm always keen to hear your views. Thanks heaps Lee Goldsworthy Product Manager - MoodleCloud

ResponsesInList.Title: MoodleCloud & unprecedented demand from COVID-19: Impacts and next steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, MoodleCloud are currently experiencing staggering new demand (more than 20,000 new schools and businesses in the last 10 days), and I wanted to share the impacts of this increased demand, and a few things that we're doing in MoodleCloud to respond to this. 1. Infrastructure Uptime - We have succeeded in keeping all services up during this period by staying one step ahead of the hard bottlenecks that would have otherwise caused outages at specific threshholds of users/sites. This has been our focus (to the exclusion of all else) over the last 10 days. 2. Infrastructure Performance - We have not succeeded in maintaining fast page load times during this period (as this has been secondary to #1 above). We are now at the final stages of testing and expect to add capacity for more sites and concurrent users in the EU and US regions today and tomorrow. We expect these upcoming changes to substantially improve performance to usual page load times, but until then, users in EU and US regions will see slower page load times during their local business hours peak times. 3. Customer Support - We have not succeeded in maintaining our usual ticket respond/resolve times during this period. We have added support staff to the MoodleCloud team and are training them as we speak to assist with bringing down support ticket respond/resolve times. I understand this experience is challenging for you at a time when you need Moodle most, and for that I would like to apologise. Please know that the MoodleCloud team are doing everything we can right now to get back to providing a great service to you, and to the 20,000+ new schools and businesses that have signed up to MoodleCloud in the last 10 days alone. Hit me up below if you have any questions or concerns, I'd love to hear them. Cheers Lee Goldsworthy Product Manager - MoodleCloud

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud & unprecedented demand from COVID-19: Impacts and next steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi again everyone, I would like to apologise for yet another day of reduced performance. Our engineers attempted to deploy an upgrade today, but we chose to stop before finishing because we thought it posed too much of a risk of interrupting service for all users in the EU region. We have rescheduled completing this upgrade to 2020-03-25 23:00 and will provide an update here when I have more information. I am deeply regretful that we have not met your expectations on this occasion. The whole MoodleCloud team are working hard to resolve these performance issues as soon as possible for you. Thanks Lee Goldsworthy Product Manager - MoodleCloud

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud & unprecedented demand from COVID-19: Impacts and next steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi folks, In our ongoing efforts to restore performance we've had some wins. Short term tweaks made about an hour ago have restored operation of both EU and US regions to normal performance. These are temporary in nature to buy us some time until we finalise the upgrade in the upcoming change scheduled for 23:00 GMT+0. More information as I know it. Cheers Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud & unprecedented demand from COVID-19: Impacts and next steps
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi folks, EU region capacity upgrades were successfully completed overnight. MoodleCloud Engineers are monitoring closely to ensure this region performs optimally today and going forwards. US region has temporary performance measures in place to ensure performance is not impacted between now and this region's capacity upgrades, currently scheduled for 2020-03-26 23:00 GMT+0. Thanks again for all your patience, we're almost there! Cheers

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Deleted MoodleCloud site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi everyone, Moodle recently deleted our MoodleCloud site while we were working on other priority projects. We've made several attempts to contact Moodle Support to inquire recovering the site with no response to date. Do you have any suggestions who to contact or any other actions to take in recovering the deleted site? Thanks in advance for any feedback.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Deleted MoodleCloud site
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Truc, Please submit a request from the MoodleCloud Support page (use the top-left "Submit a request" link). It is possible, for a fee, to perform a site restore. Please note that due to high volume, the backups are only kept for a few weeks after removal, so proceed quickly. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Deleted MoodleCloud site
ResponsesInList.Text: The same happened to us. If you were using the Free version of MoodleCloud, they have a 60 day inactivity policy and after 60 days (and at least one notification - that we missed), they delete the site. Here is the message I received from support - and in a follow up i learned that after 90 days there is no chance of recovery - so, if you are willing / able to pay $100 AUD, then i would move quickly if you are in the 60-90 day window: "Sorry to hear you have lost your site, under our free site retention policy, if your Moodle for Free site has been inactive for more than 60 days, it is removed in order to maintain a vibrant and active system for all users. We do send a reminder email message before the site is removed. Your site - xxxx.moodlecloud.com was deleted on the 9 October 2019. A warning email about your inactivity on your site was sent to your email address on the 25 September 2019. To get the site back online, our technical team are able to restore your site data but as this is performed by our technical team there is a fee of $100.00 AUD to go ahead with the site restore. Also please note that to comply with our GDPR policies, as you are no longer as a customer, you will need to reply to this email for us to go ahead with the site restore within 14 days of the site deletion or your site will be deleted from our systems."

ResponsesInList.Title: Upcoming changes in the MoodleCloud Free Forever plans
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, From February 18th, 2020, weâ€™re changing the idle timer for all MoodleCloud Free sites to 14 days instead of the current 60. This means that if a Free MoodleCloud site remains inactive for 14 consecutive days, weâ€™ll e-mail the site Admin and ask them to log in to their site. If neither the Admin nor any other user log in to the site in the following 7 days, weâ€™ll delete it. By shortening this idle period, weâ€™re reducing infrastructure costs from maintaining many Free sites that are created to try MoodleCloud and later become dormant. This, in turn, means that we will have more resources to ensure that MoodleCloud Free Forever sites that are being used remain free forever. Site admins of all MoodleCloud Free sites are being notified of this change by email and via the Customer Portal. All MoodleCloud Free site owners can remove the idle timer completely by signing up for one of our paid MoodleCloud plans, starting from AU$80 / Year . Thanks! Lee Goldsworthy Product Manager - MoodleCloud

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upcoming changes in the MoodleCloud Free Forever plans

ResponsesInList.Title: Question: BigBlueButton Recording on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, we are evaluating the MoodleCloud Mini Package ($250/ year, 100 max users, File Storage 200MB) for our online classes. Wondering if anyone can help with the below questions: 1. On the mini-package, if we record a class session with bigbluebutton, where will this recording be saved? Will the saved file count towards the File Storage limit of 200mb? 2. As our class sessions are 90 minutes long, am pretty sure that any video recording will exceed 200MB, has anyone encountered this issue, and can you advise what to do to work around it? 3. We may run concurrent classes at the same time, and will require concurrent Web-conferencing sessions. Can anyone advise how many sessions could we run at the same time? 4. Is the file storage limit of 200MB site-wide for all users? It seems very low and easy to hit the limit. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question: BigBlueButton Recording on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, 1 & 2 - The short answer is that BBB recordings are managed by the BBB folks, so do not count in any way in your allocated quota. 3 - Concurrent access to BBB is fine and there is no hard limit on concurrent sessions at this time. 4 - Yes, indeed, it is fairly low and it's possible we increase this limit in the future. In any case, Moodle allows for extensive use of 3rd-party hosting services (Google drive, Dropbox, etc.) and can embed content from Youtube and other video hosting sites. I recommend taking advantage of these features to save on disk space. Looking forward to seeing your site on MoodleCloud! Mat

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Question: BigBlueButton Recording on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you very much!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change my URL in MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Yes, it's possible to do it and there are no repercussions - apart from the obvious fact any outside URL to the original site will not work anymore. We do charge a fee for this operation. Please log in to https://moodlecloud.com/app/en/portal/ and open a request from the "Support tab" if you would like to go ahead with this. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Change my URL in MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Sorry, this is a task that has to be performed server -side as it requires some operations directly in the database (like rewriting some links ), which has to be done while your site is inactive. There is a short maintenance window (a few minutes) where your site is offline while this is happening. No other operation is required from your side (no backup/restore). Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Image Gallery in MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: I have a Moodle course that I use as part of my Community College class that I teach.Â  The college uses Moodle for their LMS.Â  I would like to use this course for the high school class that I teach on the same material. I created a Moodle Cloud course to try for my high school class. My college Moodle includes Lightbox Gallery as a resource to add images for my course.Â  Â This is not an option on Moodle Cloud.Â  Do you have a recommendation for providing an image gallery in a Moodle Cloud course? Thank you Roger

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Image Gallery in MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Roger. You are correct, MoodleCloud is basically standard core Moodle (with a couple of chosen plugins) but no ability to add other plugins, such as the Lightbox Gallery plugin ( working example ). However, with a little work, you could use a Database activity or a Glossary activity as a sort of Lightbox. Glossary might be quickest and easiest (although Database would give you more display flexibility if you are happy putting some work into designing Â the templates?) A key advantage of the Glossary however is that you could then use a Random Glossary Entry Block - which could be set to show a different image every time the page is revisited or refreshed. That can work very nicely if the Block is top left / right so the users see the changing images all the time Stu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Image Gallery in MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: See the discussion Viewing pictures that students have taken and uploaded .

ResponsesInList.Title: MOODLE CLOUD - DIFFERENT QUESTIONS - MOODLE CLOUD
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Moodlers, I have some question about MoodleCloud. 1) I have already created a course on the free option of MoodleCloud, can I take everything and put it on the mini or small option or I have to create everything againÂ  when I will upgrade? 2) If I want to load a video in my mini or small option, can I do it ? Because now in the free version, I cannot do it. 3) If i take the mini or small option, can my classes be still available on the net in 10 or 50 years time or the account will expire ? The question is: If in 2 years time I want to opt for the normal Moodle and quit moodlecloud to give my classes, but i want to keep the moodlecloud version, can I still access to it ,if I do not pay anymore ? thank you very much in advance, Best margherita maria de lorenzi

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE CLOUD - DIFFERENT QUESTIONS - MOODLE CLOUD
ResponsesInList.Text: I have another question about MoodleCloud: how do I restrict access to some section or forum of my class ? Because I do not want some teacher to see or modify everything and I do not want some student to see or modify everything. Thanks again !

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE CLOUD - DIFFERENT QUESTIONS - MOODLE CLOUD
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, If you decide to upgrade to a paid plan of MoodleCloud , your current site will be upgraded. There is no need to move/rebuild what you have - everything stays as it is Since I work full-time on MoodleCloud, I sure hope it will still be online in 10 or 50 years, but there are unfortunately no guarantees about it. On a Moodle level, courses from 10 years ago can definitely still be restored in Moodle nowadays, so that's already a good thing. I feel this is a discussion as much about formats you use in your course as it is about the platform itself. In both cases, "I sure hope so and I'll do my best to make it happen" is the best I can say. You can definitely load videos in a free MoodleCloud site (though the space is limited). For both of these questions (videos and access control), since they are not MoodleCloud-specific, I strongly recommend you ask in the relevant support forum (have you tried the Assistance technique and Assistance pÃ©dagogique ?). Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MOODLE CLOUD - DIFFERENT QUESTIONS - MOODLE CLOUD
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok perfect thank you very much !!!

ResponsesInList.Title: Influence of suspended MoodleCloud service for 'offline' users
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi We have a Moodle cloud site and the subscription is coming up for renewal in a few weeks. Most/all our users currently access the content offline through the Moodle app. We're in the process of determining whether Moodle Cloud is the right place for the site for the next year, or if we need to move it elsewhere (depending on a number of factors). Due to red tape, it could happen that a final decision is not made by the time the subscription comes up from renewal. How will users accessing content offline through the app be affected? Will they still have access until they go online again, or will their access stop the same day subscription is suspended (if it isn't paid). Having all the facts will help prioritise decision making. Thanks. Jessica

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Influence of suspended MoodleCloud service for 'offline' users
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jessica, Sorry to hear you might have to leave MoodleCloud . The offline availability of content in the Moodle app depends on the each activity. I suggest you turn the wifi & data connection off on your phone and see what works and what doesn't once you're "offline". I am unfortunately not sure if the app reacts differently in the case where the connection is not "offline", but the site is suspended. Either way, I would strongly suggest you download both a course backup from your site, and a full site export from the MoodleCloud portal (under the "Tools" tab in the portal). Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Influence of suspended MoodleCloud service for 'offline' users
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mathieu Thank you for your reply. Great tip on the course backup - thank you. I'll make sure to do that just in case. Kind regards Jessica

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add Google Analytics to MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Monty, Has you have seen, the additionalhtmlhead config option is indeed locked on MoodleCloud for security reasons. Unfortunately, I don't think there is a way to use Google Analytics on your MoodleCloud site at this time. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add Google Analytics to MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Even if you could track you site with Google Analytics, don't do it! Google is a surveillance infrastructure of unimaginable dimensions and they abuse your data. The very special irony of Google Analytics is that Google doesn't have to do anything actively, it is you, the webmaster, who sends data on each click of your users to Google. So you are sending other's data to Google. The law is catching up with this abuse and it is on the way to become illegal. Even now the major browsers have mechanisms built-in to block this communication. This is too broad a topic, or rather a whole bag of issues, to be discussed here. But unavoidable we touch it many forums on moodle.org. Here is a random short explanation I found: https://webmasters.stackexchange.com/questions/50824/what-are-the-security-implications-of-using-google-analytics . Please inform yourself. Generally people don't like to be tracked. There are so many tools and methods to find out whether a site is tracking. So finally the tracking can back-fire depending on the awareness of your users. If you have the trust of users, why don't you collect data transparently? Everybody knows that each click is "trackable" if one is logged in.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add Google Analytics to MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks everyone for your help with this. I did notice that you can put it into the html body and it works just fine. Having said that we may not even need the analytics portion at this stage based on my discussions with my client as we mainly need reporting details which moodle already supports so I think we are good.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add Google Analytics to MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Interesting to know, since Google's documentation specifically requests the tag to be in the "head" section.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Add Google Analytics to MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Glad that you could avoid Google. See this recent discussion: Surveillance Giants: How the business model of Google and Facebook threatens human rights .

It's often this cycle: Click on the Azure AD sign on, select my account, get error, click continue, repeat. When I click on "More information about this error" it takes me to this site: https://docs.moodle.org/36/en/error/moodle/invalidsesskey .Â Should we be checking out these options or is this likely a different kind of issue? However, we always select "Manual accounts" when we create users, so I'm unsure how some say "OAuth2" or if that is in any way connected to the issue we are having. ResponsesInList.Title: HP5 in Moodle Cloud School
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi I understand HP5 is now a core plugin in Moodle.Â  However, I can't find out anywhere whether there are plans to include it as a core in Moodle Cloud or as an extra plugin in Moodle School. Many thanks Brendan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: HP5 in Moodle Cloud School
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Brendan, In Moodle 3.8, work on core integration of H5P was started, but not completed. I gather you'd still need the 3rd party plugin to create H5P content directly in your Moodle instance. For now, significant steps have been made to allow for easier embedding of H5P content in any text area through the ATTO editor, and the filter to make sure the H5P content is displayed correctly in those text areas. I expect the mod_hvp to become part of Moodle core by 3.9 (May 2020), as can be read in the Developer's Moodle Docs : https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Roadmap

ResponsesInList.Title: BigBlueButton has Breakout Rooms Now - Thank you
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello I just discovered that the BigBlueButton activity in MoodleCloud now has break out rooms. Fantastic! Thank you very much for including breakout rooms now in MoodleCloud.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton has Breakout Rooms Now - Thank you
ResponsesInList.Text: Bonjour FranÃ§ois, The limit is not set by MoodleCloud , it's a BigBlueButton default and is hardcoded to 8: https://support.blindsidenetworks.com/hc/en-us/articles/360024516512-Create-and-manage-breakout-rooms I am not aware of the reasons of this limit or if there are any plans to change that eventually. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton has Breakout Rooms Now - Thank you
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Mathieu, Great link, thank you.Â  I found a similar question on the BigBlueButton saying while the number of rooms are set at 8, there is not a limit on the number of users. --> There's a cap of 8 breakout rooms in a meeting. The user cap is more fluid. There are no hardcoded user limits in BigBlueButton so the biggest factor is server specs and then client bottlenecks. For the current HTML5 client build I would recommend not going over 100 users in a meeting and to reach those numbers requires a server that is beyond the minimum specs in the documentation. We're trying to raise the number of users that the client can sustain, but it's an ongoing process. https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/bigbluebutton-users/6hjfvfWNAsY/fwnu_CeNCAAJ

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: BigBlueButton has Breakout Rooms Now - Thank you
ResponsesInList.Text: Merci mon cher! And I understand that this limit is not only for MoodleCloud users, but for all Blindside Networks users, since you are pointing towards their general documentation. Good to know.

ResponsesInList.Title: Migrating old moodle to moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, We have an old training module on our web server that is built on an old version of Moodle (2.61) and it apparently requires an older version of PHP than what is running on our server today. I am wondering if I could just migrate it to moodle cloud to get it up to speed.Â  Is it possible to migrate an existing legacy moodle instance to the cloud and work on it there? Or c an I configure a Moodle cloud account to accommodate this older version of the training module?Â  Specifically run an old version of PHP to accommodate an older version of Moodle?Â  As I write this I am thinking this is probably not possible as it is probably some kind of shared hosting, but I am hoping that using the cloud version will be an easier environment to updgrade it to ver 3.7. Thoughts on migrating an old Moodle app to the Moodle Cloud? Hopefully I am making sense and thanks for any help you can give me. - Joe

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrating old moodle to moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Joe, Long story short - no, MoodleCloud does not offer older versions of Moodle. As you found out, since Moodle 2.6.1 does not support php 7, you will have a hard time finding a commercial host that will offer you this service. At this point, you can contact a Moodle Partner (find yours on https://moodle.com/partners/ ) to ask for support. They should be able to provide help. Otherwise, if you have a backup of your course, you can try to upload it into a MoodleCloud siteÂ  and see how things goÂ­. If you do not use contrib modules, your content should be upgraded and work in the up-to-date Moodle version MoodleCloud provides. Let us know how it goes, Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Guest Access not working
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I saw that some others had posted on this topic but the posts were over a year old and didn't have a clear resolution. I'm running into an issue with Moodle Cloud where I've enabled guest access but guests are still being required to create a username/password rather than logging in as guest. I went to Participants > Settings (gear icon) > Guest Access > Allow Guest Access > Yes I've tried this with and without a guest password. I've also tried disabling guest access and re-enabling. Both of these icons also appear to the right of the course name on my homepage: Could there be another setting somewhere that would potentially interfere with this one? I am hoping there's a way to fix this without having to start all over. Thanks, Brittany

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Guest Access not working
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Brittany, A small point of confusion to begin with: "guest" may refer to both "authentication" and "enrolment". Previous questions on this topic referred to "authentication" (which controls access to the site, usually with a username and password), while the screenshot you pasted is about the "guest enrolment" (access to a course). Unfortunately, as you saw in other threads (but mostly this one - linked here for whoever comes next with this question),Â Â this option is not available on the free version of MoodleCloud , mostly as a way to prevent abuse. You can use autologinguests to achieve a somewhat similar result, but it's probably not a great behaviour for your site, as explained in the linked thread. You can still enable guest access to courses, but in your case (and unless you enable autologinguests ), it means that logged-in users will be able to access the course material, even though they might not be enrolled in that course. Hopefully this helps, but I'm aware I might not be explaining this in the most simple way. Let us know how it goes. You may also find more help in the General help forum . More information about enrolment is available on https://docs.moodle.org/37/en/Course_enrolment Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Guest Access not working
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Brittany. This page with a couple of videos might also be helpful: Enable guest access

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud to WordPress
ResponsesInList.Text: Edwiser requires two elements: one plugin on the WordPress side and one plugin on the Moodle side. As you canâ€™t install additional plugins on MoodleCloud , you cannot use Edwiser. On a hosted Moodle platform, you can install whatever plugins you need but not on MoodleCloud.

ResponsesInList.Title: Transferring users
ResponsesInList.Text: Good day to all. Currently I am moving a moodle site from my local server to the MoodleCloud. I wish to know if it is also possible to copy accounts from it to there. Or will my students have to make new ones? (They have already filled in all the user data) Thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Transferring users
ResponsesInList.Text: You could use Bulk User Actions to create a download file of your current users and then upload users to your Moodle cloud site. The only thing youâ€™ll lose is their password, which can easily be reset in bulk or individually - everything else will be transferrred. If you're backing up courses from your old site though, you can include enrolled user data and new accounts will be created on your new site for the restored courses. Youâ€™ll still need to sort the passwords though.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Transferring users

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Transferring users
ResponsesInList.Text: You could use that, or use a generic password in the upload file and tell them by email when youâ€™re ready.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Migrate from Moodle for Windows on pc to MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes you can. However, there are file limits on MoodleCloud (particularly the free version) so if your courses contain a lot of large sized files eg videos and powerpoints, you should first host them elsewhere eg YouTube, GoogleDrive etc. But other than that there is nothing stopping you moving your courses to MoodleCloud.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud Course Access for Students as Guests
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes there is... but I am not real sure this is wise. The only restriction will be the number of users your MC site is limited to. This should work but it's a bit fiddly to set up. Go to each course and Course Admin > Enrolment Methods change the preferred enrollment method to Self Enrolment. Do not set an Enrolment Key, or if you are required to, then make that key simple and generic, advertise it on the Front Page .Â  If you have all your courses, or rather just one course on the Front Page, then simply setting your Role on Front Page to Student might work, but it might not.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud Course Access for Students as Guests
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Shari, Please have a look at the following thread for some info and background: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=374734 Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud Course Access for Students as Guests
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Shari. For guests to access your courses the admin needs to enable guest access and then the courses themselves must have guest access. Please read the documentation Guest access , especiallyÂ  the bit about auto-login guests. Be aware that guests are not able to complete all activities; some they can only view. They should be able to do lessons with guest access however. See the documentation Guest role for which activities they canNOT do.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud Course Access for Students as Guests

This is MoodleCloud and I have no access to the server. The connection log records the login attempt as successful and I have to log out to be able to log in under my name in the same browser. The issue affects four students, three in South Africa and one in Europe who have used Moodle intensively in past weeks, including to open another website containing course content. I have searched the Internet and Moodle forum for a similar issue but have found no occurrence. It is getting serious and I would very much appreciate help.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some students cannot access their course anymore - "Too many redirects" error
ResponsesInList.Text: Bonjour Claude, Please open a ticket from support.moodlecloud.com and send us the name of one or two of these students, so we can try it on our side. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Some students cannot access their course anymore - "Too many redirects" error
ResponsesInList.Text: After investigation, this appears to be triggered by a Moodle core bug, having to do with a policy having been created with 'active' status and later inactivated. Making it active will let users agree to that policy ... or the admin can manually accept the policy on behalf of the users (with their knowledge of it, obviously). See MDL-65006 for details and followup. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Impact Of Deleting A User & Re-Using The Vacancy
ResponsesInList.Text: I am wondering if we can delete a user (student) from the MoodleCloud application, and what will the impact be on the courses in which that user has been enrolled in. We are currently on the 100-user package and it is estimated in about 3 to 4 months' time we will hit the 100% quota. Courses run by us are not long - 3 months to 6 months on the average. And some students will not continue with us after they have finished their chosen courses though they can opt to continue with other related courses. Can we delete such students from our users database and re-use the empty slots without breaking the courses that these students were enrolled in (in terms of grades and contributions from such deleted students)? Or would all information (grades & contributions) of such students be wiped clean as well? Would appreciate guidance on this so that we can make decision whether to increase the quota when the time comes. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Impact Of Deleting A User & Re-Using The Vacancy
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric, As far as the user limit on MoodleCloud is concerned, once you delete a user, you can create a new one. I'll leave it to someone more qualified than me to answer your question about what happens to grades after user removal. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Impact Of Deleting A User & Re-Using The Vacancy
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I can confirm that if you delete a student, then their grades and contributions are also deleted. However, you can prevent forum posts from being deleted if you manually delete the student via Site administration / Users / Accounts / Browse list of users and the setting 'Create automatic data deletion requests' (in Site administration / Users / Privacy and policies / Privacy settings) is NOT ticked. (If the setting is ticked, then the forum post content is removed.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Impact Of Deleting A User & Re-Using The Vacancy
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Helen, for the valuable input. That will help us plan our classes accordingly. Cheers Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Impact Of Deleting A User & Re-Using The Vacancy
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Mathieu. Appreciate the reply. Cheers Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error message when taking quizzes
ResponsesInList.Text: You are right that this is the second time an issue like this has been reported. However, the first report did not give enough clues to work out what was going. In moodle, the 'course modules' database table is what links all the different activities and resources (quizzes, forums, pages, labels, ...) to the course. This part of Moodle has not changed in years, and normally works fine, so it is hard to guess what might be causing this error. We need more facts. It would be very helpful if you could turn on Debugging , and set it to 'Developer' level and trigger the error again. Then copy and paste the full error message here. That would tell us exactly where in the code the error is coming from.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error message when taking quizzes
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sarra and Tim, Unfortunately, debugging is not available on MoodleCloud, but the issue is now quite well documented in both https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-64878 and https://tracker.moodle.org/browse/MDL-64895 . Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No guest access on MoodleCloud (free version)?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Visvanath and Mary, I think you are looking for autologinguests under Admin -> User policies. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No guest access on MoodleCloud (free version)?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Mathieu (and anyone who comes to this thread subsequently) This discussion is a follow up from the forum thread mentioned by Visvanath above where he asks how to have his guest access courses available immediately without the need to click on the log in as guest button. I suggested he use "autologinguests" and showed my MoodleCloud site as an example. This then prompted us to discuss here the strange fact that, if your site has forcelogin - yes, as all the MoodleCloud sites do, then you would expect not to be able to do this, but in fact, the autologinguests setting means you can have guest access on a site where you are not allowed to see the front page before logging in. I looked in the tracker and found several very old issues about this: for example MDL-35359 and MDL-10850 which seem to suggest that this is the expected behaviour: Sites with forcelogin can indeed still have autologinguests. (I am about to edit the documentation to clarify this)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: No guest access on MoodleCloud (free version)?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Priyanka, As discussed above, this option is not available on the free version of MoodleCloud, mostly as a way to prevent abuse. You can use autologinguests to achieve a somewhat similar result. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Email-based self-registration occasionally fails
ResponsesInList.Text: I tested myself with the "Email-based self-registration" plug-in, creating some fake accounts and I've always been successful. So I used that authentication method to collect accounts from my students. Well, some of them were successful with the registration, but the rest of the class encountered a problem: when they pressed the button "Create my new account" (immediately after reCaptcha recognition), the email wasn't sent and the authentication process has been restarted automatically (from the "privacy notification" page, onwards). I told them to try again, but they continued to experience the same problem. During these attempts, some students successfully completed the procedure. Finally, first one student, then another student, all managed to register on my Moodle site. I thought the "Email-based self-registration" plug-in failed when more students try to use it at the same time. Anyway, a few days later, I tried the registration process with another class: still the same problem. The first 3-4 students immediately completed the registration successfully. Others after several attempts, one student at a time. My questions: Have you ever experienced this "strange" behaviour of the "Email-based self-registration" plug-in? What could be the reason? What can I do, in the future, to manage the email-based registration process without proceed with one student at a time? Thanks in advance, Luigi P.S. I use Moodle 3.5, hosted by MoodleCloud.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Email-based self-registration occasionally fails
ResponsesInList.Text: I would suspect that this is an issue with your email server .Â  I know that I had problems using Gmail as the outgoing server, that it would send a few emails and then stall out.Â  I had to change the setting to allow for multiple emails to be sent in one session.Â  Apparently, sending a single email at a time was causing too many logins to the gmail server and it would shut down for a while.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Email-based self-registration occasionally fails
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot, could you tell me how I can change the outgoing-email settings on my Moodle site?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Email-based self-registration occasionally fails
ResponsesInList.Text: MoodleCloud? Are you on a paid plan? In the free plan you can not change the outgoing mail configuration. Watch for the blue "Defined in config.php" text. If you are on a paid plan, ask the moderator to move your post to the MoodleCloud forum https://moodle.org/mod/forum/view.php?id=8277 .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Email-based self-registration occasionally fails

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Email-based self-registration occasionally fails
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Luigi (and everyone else in this thread), After looking this up on the MoodleCloud servers, our service is behaving normally. ResponsesInList.Title: Free plan: Just created the  space, can't login
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi. Yesterday I created a space. At the end of the process I was auto-logined to the space. TodayÂ  the session was time-out. Every attempt to re-login failed no matter if I usedÂ  admin, the space name,Â  or my email address as a username. I still can login to the portal using the space name and the given password. What can I do? Any help appreciated.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Free plan: Just created the  space, can't login
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ray, You can change your password via your MoodleCloud site login screen or the MoodleCloud Portal login if you are the site admin user. First, go to your site login screen. Moodle for Free and Starter site URLs have this format: [yoursitename].moodlecloud.com. Moodle for School site URLs have this format: [yoursitename].moodle.school. Second, locate the link: forgotten your username or password? You will be redirected to a page that asks you to enter your username or email address. Once youâ€™ve entered your information an email will be sent to the email address you registered with, instructing you on how to change your password. Itâ€™s important to remember if you are the site admin user, a password reset applies to the admin user on your MoodleCloud site and the portal login. They will always have the same password. I hope this information helps. If you are still having issues, I suggest you email the support team at support@moodlecloud.com Happy Moodling! Frances

ResponsesInList.Text: Frances, Thanks a lot for your support. Actually if the password is working at the portal it should work at the site as well. I tried already requesting a forgotten password with my email address but I didn't receive any notification. I'll try to contact support@moodlecloud.com then. ray()

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Export course settings to file
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Tim, Create a backup of your course. This will give you a ".mbz" file (which is really a zip file). In there, you'll find an xml "description" of the course under course/course.xml . There is more to a course, but that's the basic configuration of it, in a machine-readable format. You might prefer printing a PDF of the course "edit settings" page, as Howard suggested above. I'll be annoying and point out there's no such thing as "Moodlecloud 3.5.1". All MoodleCloud sites are upgraded to the latest Moodle version as soon as possible after a release. All sites were upgraded to 3.5.2 last week. Mat

ResponsesInList.Title: SCORM file too large
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to load a SCORM file that exceeds the 199.9MB limit. The file was provided by a third party and it has been successfully installed before. Is this a Moodle Cloud issue and I will need to move 'regular' Moodle?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: SCORM file too large
ResponsesInList.Text: It is, unfortunately, a current MoodleCloud limit. You could upgrade to the MoodleCloud medium plan, but that file would likely still take most of your allocated space. Moving to your own (self-hosted) Moodle, or possibly to Moodle hosting from a Moodle Partner would indeed help solve this problem. Not knowing what's in that scorm file, it's hard to suggest other things, but sometimes it's possible to host some bigs files (often videos) elsewhere and have the scorm file link to these ressources. I know this breaks the "self-encapsulation" of the scorm package, but it could make it possible to use MoodleCloud for you. Mat

ResponsesInList.Title: Boost theme preset
ResponsesInList.Text: My Moodle Cloud site has a boost colorfunction preset, and all of a sudden it has stopped working. It is still there, still selected, but not doing anything.Â  Three days ago, it looks from the logs as if I logged in and changed some system files, but I didn't.Â  Any ideas? I can attach the log.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Boost theme preset
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Linda, Moodle 3.5 upgraded the bootstrap theme library which requires all pre 3.5 boost preset files to be upgraded to the new format. If Moodle detects an old (broken) preset, it will revert back to Moodle default of no preset, which would explain what you are seeing. Please ensure your preset file is Moodle 3.5 compatible, you can read more about that here: https://docs.moodle.org/35/en/Upgrading#Possible_issues_that_may_affect_you_in_Moodle_3.5 and here https://docs.moodle.org/dev/Updating_a_boost_based_theme

ResponsesInList.Title: Are Ghostscript and Unoconv considered plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: That is, the grade feature seems to require them, and the feature appears as part of my moodlecloud site, but I don't know how to install and use them, or if they are plugins (and thus not available on moodlecloud)? Any help greatly appreciated. SL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Are Ghostscript and Unoconv considered plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Sarra, Unoconv isn't a plugin in a Moodle sense. It is a command line tool which Moodle uses. On MoodleCloud sites there is the "MoodleCloud Converter" - read more about it here https://support.moodle.com/hc/en-us/articles/115003118111-What-is-MoodleCloud-Converter- The MoodleCloud Converter is included on
Starter and Moodle for School plans. If you are subscribed to one of
these plans, it is available and enabled by default. If you upgrade from a Free plan, it will be enabled automatically when the upgrade is completed. I hope this helps. Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Are Ghostscript and Unoconv considered plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you so much for your reply. Does that mean that it is not able to be enabled on a free plan, or that it is not enabled by default but can be enabled? Sarra

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Are Ghostscript and Unoconv considered plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sarra, Yes. It means you cannot enable it on a free plan. If you upgrade your site to a Starter plan for $80 AUD/year then this feature will be available to you. Please see the link below for more information: https://moodlecloud.com/app/en/ Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Can I customize my MoodleCloud URL
ResponsesInList.Text: Greetings, I have a self hosted Moodle site; www.mymoodlesite.com . I now have a MoodleCloud hosted site; mymoodlesite.moodlecloud.com. I set up a redirect from my URL and I arrive at mymoodlesite.moodlecloud.com but, obviously, the URL displayed in the address bar is mymoodlesite.moodlecloud.com. I would really like it to read mymoodlesite.com. Is this possible? How would I go about setting this up. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Can I customize my MoodleCloud URL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Edward, No, unfortunately this is not possible. If you have set up a HTTP 301 redirect from your self-hosted Moodle site then this will be a permanent redirect meaning the browsers/users will not attempt to request the original location any more and use the new one instead. A HTTP 302 redirect would be temporary. Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: About Moodlle cloud - Plans
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I'm beginning to use Moodle cloud so I have some questions about it. 1. Should I use moodle seft-hosting or Plans - moodle cloud. It cost about 61 USD. 2. Where I can take a list of plugins which "Plans - moodle cloud" support? Are they useful? Thank all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: About Moodlle cloud - Plans
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Hoang, There is a long thread which discussed the pros and cons of self-hosting , vps and other options in comparison to Moodlecloud, but the difference is massive, both in limitations and responsibilities. MoodleCloud Starter only provides the "custom certificate" extra plugin and does not allow installation of custom themes or plugins (which is possible when self-hosting). You can view the list of extra plugins on https://moodlecloud.com/app/en/ , by clicking on the "+" sign right of "Extra plugin pack". A list with more detailed descriptions is available on https://moodle.org/plugins/browse.php?list=set&id=80 - note that most of them are only available on "school plans" (which are available to anyone, don't let the name confuse you). Since MoodleCloud offers a free tier from which you can later upgrade, I would suggest you get started with it. You can later export your courses and import them into your self-hosted site if you wish. Hopefully this helps make sense of it. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Getting the H5P plugin on to the MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Is there any interest in trying to get the H5P plugin available on moodlecloud.com sites?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting the H5P plugin on to the MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: I suspect there is interest, but I am not anticipating any action for a quite a while. H5P is rather lovely, but it is very new, and even newer for Moodle. There is also the issue that much of it is client side which could be rather interesting if people use it for high stakes assessment.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting the H5P plugin on to the MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: MoodleCloud, AFAIK , is the standard/default distro of modules in Moodle; no extra bells and whistles. Wouldn't H5P need to be accepted and supported as part of the standard distro to be on MoodleCloud or are there other considerations? Rather than being yet another summative assessment tool, which H5P can be used for, I see it as more of a replacement for other presentation formats, e.g. Flash and multimedia slideshows, which often include in-line quizzes and games in an attempt to improve students' recall of the content. I don't consider any of the modules in the standard Moodle distro as serving that function particularly well (e.g. Quiz and Lesson modules) and this is where H5P excels. I think the main usability issue with the H5P Moodle module, i.e. authoring content, still needs to be resolved. At the moment, users have to use another platform to author content rather than doing it all in Moodle. This replicates the editing problems with using SCORM packages. It'll be interesting to see where this goes.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting the H5P plugin on to the MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: You are right about MoodleCloud being an almost stock delivery of Moodle core but H5P now has editing technology right there in the Moodle plugin, which is rather impressive. For me it has the advantage over SCORM of not being SCORM . I think it would be possible to link from a MoodleCloud account using LTI to a site with H5P.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting the H5P plugin on to the MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Ah, that's good news. Last time I looked, a few weeks ago, we still had to create content in Wordpress or Drupal. For me, in line content creation and editing in Moodle for H5P is a must. Nice to see that the projects moving forwards in leaps and bounds

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Getting the H5P plugin on to the MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, when I first looked at it you had to create the content in another tool (I used Wordpress). There is talk of adding server side functionality to some of it which would make it more attractive for summative assessment. Norways http://joubel.com/ are doing some awesome work.

ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Azmat. You may use MoodleCloud for any kind of training and learning, but as you have realised, there are limitations to the product. ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Modifying my.cnf
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Chat, MoodleCloud does not run on MySQL , so this is not the issue you are having. Are you possibly trying to restore a single activity backup as a course? ResponsesInList.Title: Debugging options are not changing in moodle cloud.
ResponsesInList.Text: I am trying to change debugging options in Site Administration -> Development -> Debugging. But when i am changing options and submitted it is not reflecting. So i am unable to trace the issue which is coming in webservices which i created. Please help in changing debugging option in my https://<CloudName>.moodlecloud.com/

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Debugging options are not changing in moodle cloud.
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Any admin settings on your MoodleCloud site which have 'Defined in config.php' under the setting name (such as Debug messages) can't be changed. Thus, if you want to debug a web service, you'll need to set up your own Moodle site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Debugging options are not changing in moodle cloud.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lost/Deleted? the Sample Course
ResponsesInList.Text: Check the Recycle bin of Moodle https://docs.moodle.org/31/en/Recycle_bin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Lost/Deleted? the Sample Course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Gina, Unfortunately, the Recycle bin feature is currently disabled on MoodleCloud. If you have access to another MoodleCloud site, you can do a backup of that course from that site and import it into yours. Otherwise, please open a request on our support system from the portal and we'll help you out from there. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud 'Introduction to Moodle' course

ResponsesInList.Title: number of users take exams in the same time in moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: hi, how many users take quiz in the same time in moodle cloud (free plan- 50 users)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: number of users take exams in the same time in moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eman, MoodleCloud only limits the number of user accounts, so all your users can take the quiz at the same time. In a free site, accounting for one teacher (which in such a case would probably be the admin account), this means you can have 49 students taking a quiz at once. (For completeness, I'll add that the teacher could do it too, since that account can also be enrolled in the course as a student, but I'm guessing that's not what you're after.) Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Paiment for Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi All, I have a question about Moodle paiment.Â  I wanted to extend 200MB and pay with Paypal when a message came up that said "...The money will automatically be taken from your account every year" How is this possible? What are the consequences if I stop using Moodle? (I initially contacted Moodle by email for support but it's been a week now so I thought I'd ask here) Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Paiment for Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Firstly, this is the place for free support, not by email. If you need paid support, please speak to a Moodle Partner. The only built in payment plugin is Paypal which is quite limited. There are other solutions that generally integrate Moodle with an eCommerce platform. WooCommerce is quite a common one.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Paiment for Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Matt - are you talking about the MoodleCloud options here? Did you get one of these? https://moodlecloud.com/app/en/ Have you seen the MoodleCloud FAQ here? If you don't want to useÂ  your MoodleCloud site in future years, you can either just leave it or you can export the whole site to use somewhere else.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Paiment for Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Ahh.... I see now. I completely misunderstood what he was asking

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Paiment for Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello! The thing is, I am on a free MOodle teaching website and it's now full. (200MB or whatever it is, are full of my courses) I am told I have to purchase to extend the space on my Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Paiment for Moodle
ResponsesInList.Text: Well Matt, if you are on the free MoodleCloud site then the links I gave you before will give you the details. You only have 200 MB space because you are expected to make links to your documents from other places online like Google drive, Dropbox or YouTube - and you can still do that if you want. You can get rid of your 200 MB by putting some of your files somewhere elseÂ  and then you can keep the free site. But if you prefer to have more storage space then, according to the MoodleCloud rules you will have to pay. I just want to add by the way that Moodle software IS actually entirely free and open source to anyone who wants it and is able to install it on a server . You do still have to pay for the hosting. MoodleCLoud is just a quick and easy (official) way of having this done for you so you can focus on the teaching.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Trouble with the My Courses menu
ResponsesInList.Text: OK so.. a few things to check.. Admins won't by default see anything in the My courses link because they automatically have acess to all courses. You need to enrol them as teachers into a course (althought arguably if they are going to be teaching they should have a separate login) A usual reason correctly enrolled participants don't see their courses in the My courses tab is that the course start date is the future (or the end) No need to edit themes

ResponsesInList.Title: MoodleCloud - Installing Plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: I would like to install several Moodle approved plugins (from the downloads/plugins page at Moodle.org) to my MoodleCloud courses.Â  I cannot locate where and how to update/add a plugin when I am in a course developed in MoodleCloud?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud - Installing Plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi John, At this time, you are unable to add any plugins to a MoodleCloud site: https://support.moodle.com/hc/en-us/articles/115009354828-Does-MoodleCloud-allow-plugins- Take care,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud - Installing Plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I want to ask you about these plugins, are they safe and are they really useful plugins ?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud - Installing Plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Rajesh, Are you asking about the plugins that are included as part of a Moodle for School package? I am going to assume so. Those plugins are safe in that they have been tested extensively by the MoodleCloud team to work. If there were some known security issue related to them, I am very confident that the team would have pounced on it for sure. As far as useful goes, a hammer is not so handy for sewing, but pretty good for smacking in nails ... these plugins are very useful for many a teaching situation, but as we all know, not all teaching situations are alike. In my circumstances, the Attendance module is not so useful as I have been required to take attendance using another system; if I didn't have that requirement, it would be extremely useful to me. Group Choice is spectacularly useful with my students. I have rarely used a teleconferencing solution such as Big Blue Button with my classes, but it might be a daily occurrence in your case, so extremely useful to you. When I *do* want to offer an interview with an expert to my students, however, having the option available is really valuable. Do you think that Checklist could help your students (and you, and even their parents) keep track of their requirements, progress and completed material? I do. And if you are teaching with material that needs the Equation or Chemistry editors and they weren't available, how many hairs would remain on your head? Maybe we would all love a few more plugins to suit our particular situation, but these ones have been tested with the MoodleCloud themes, and they are stable - is "reassuring" the safety that you are looking for? At the end of the day, I think that I might be saying that it's not just what we've got through Moodle for School, but how we use it ... or am I saying something like beauty is in the eye of the beholder? HTH ,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: MoodleCloud - Installing Plugins?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Brent Parkin, Thanks for reply, I hope the plugins which is I'm using is right for me. If I get any problem I want to contact you. So please help for me. Thanks in advance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle App Customization for MoodleCloud Free course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello all... Very new to MoodleCloud... but ABSOLUTELY LOVE WHAT WE CAN DO WITH IT! We've been able to customize logos, colors, font sizes, etc. via CSS on the Desktop site.Â  But after much searching and research, we can't seem to figure out how to customize the css for the app side of things. I know there's a field under Mobile App > Mobile Appearance for a custmoized css file.Â  Not exactly sure where the file should be stored or if there's a template file that can be used to plug and play the styles we would like to change. Any/all help would be welcome!Â  Thanks much!Â  -Todd

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle App Customization for MoodleCloud Free course
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Todd, we usually recommend the file to be stored in the same server as the Moodle site to have everything in the same place. In the case of Moodle cloud , you can use any server or service that allows you to publish public files. For example, in one of our testing sites we use a gist in GitHub, so the URL is something like: https://gist.githubusercontent.com/user/.../moodlemobileapp.css I think you should be able to use some services like Dropbox or Google Drive as long as the file is public and you provide the download link in there. Please notice there shouldn't be any "intermediary" page when opening the link, it should be a direct link to the file. In 2016 I did a presentation about customizing styles in the MoodleMoot US, here are the slides: https://www.slideshare.net/DaniPalouSala/creating-moodle-mobile-remote-themes-moodle-moot-us-2016 Hopefully they will help you Kind regards, Dani

ResponsesInList.Title: Student Enrollment
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I enrolled a student to the moodlecloud and when she tries to login to the Spanish 101 courseroom, it tells her that she can't enroll herself. She should be able to enter the course room since I manually enrolled her, but it won't let her in. Thank you, Kevin white

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student Enrollment
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kevin, It seems like the student has a valid user account, which allows her to login, but she is not enrolled in the course (which is a different operation). The Moodle documentation explains how to do that in details and this short video also shows how to do it, but the short story is: go to the course front page in the left menu, click "Participants" then, in the "gear menu" (on the right side), click "Enrolled users" then, click on the "Enrol user button" from there you can click "Enrol" for each student you want in that course If you want users to be able to self-enrol, you need to enable the "Self enrolment" plugin for this course. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student Enrollment
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mathieu, Thank you for your timely response. I figured it out I believe. She wasn't enrolled in the course because I set up the course incorrectly. I had to delete the course and recreate it. I was then able to enroll her into the

Now, to help answer your question, the message indicates that "Error output" has been turned on (that's a preference in your configuration underÂ /admin/settings.php?section=debugging in your Moodle site - and which should never be done on a production site) and thatÂ automatic redirection are prevented.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Cloud to replace Moodle Hosting
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, Installing Moodle on a server and hosting it yourself, or even through a partner, is quite a difficult and frustrating task. Even when using a partner there are several issues to deal with, such as lack of tech support and communication issues. My question is, what is the ultimate goal of Moodle Cloud ? Is it to essentially to do away with Moodle Hosting? In the near future, will Moodle Hosting be a thing of the past? Will Moodle Cloud eventually cost money? I am all for moving away from Moodle Hosting partners and going directly through Moodle Cloud when it becomes powerful enough. Just wondering if I am on the right track with this assumption. Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud to replace Moodle Hosting
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't work for Moodle HQ, but my guess is the answer is: No. I think Moodle cloud exists to give a low barrier to entry for people just starting with Moodle, or who want a very small site with minimal support. Hosting a large Moodle site is still a serious undertaking, so there will continue to be a market where people can buy that from a range of commercial suppliers, especially Moodle partners. And, the whole point of open source is the flexibility it gives, so there will still be many people who take Moodle, customise it, and host it themselves, to get exactly the solution they want.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud to replace Moodle Hosting
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Sami, These are all great questions. Tim, while not working for Moodle HQ has answered them very well - Thanks Tim! The goal of MoodleCloud is to help as many users as possible get started with a Moodle site. It's a service that allows anyone to experience Moodle within minutes and helps users build a Moodle site to a certain level (500 users and 1Gb of file storage). As we offer limited support, we feel once you get to that level, you are ready for that next step and Moodle Partners can offer a more tailored solution and provide the necessary support and assistance for hosting a large site. As Tim mentions, the flexibility of Moodle means you can shape the solution that's right for you and choosing an appropriate hosting option is part of this. So it's likely that Moodle hosting will continue to will come in many shapes and sizes from many providers. Thanks Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Images pixels logo, course description, badges

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Images pixels logo, course description, badges
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Michelle, About the school theme: The logo preferred aspect ratio is 6:1 with a height of 80 pixels. The course image will be cropped to a height of 175 pixels, the width depends on how many courses are displayed, image will be cropped accordingly The open badges specification ask for file that has a square aspect ratio, is at least 90x90 pixels and less than 256kb in size. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: I have set up a site in Moodlecloud. I'm having problems customizing the site. I have discovered that when a visitor goes to the site, he is taken directly to the login page. Do you have any idea how is it possible to edit language strings, or Moodlecloud does not admit this, either? Thank you. Enrique

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Enrique, You can put instructions for login and sign up in Site administration > Plugins > Authentication > Manage authentication > Instructions. If you need to give more directions or other content to everyone after users log in, you can also setÂ  them to go the Site front page instead of their user Dashboard by setting Site administration > Appearance > Navigation > Default home page for users to Site.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Randy, very useful information. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: You're welcome. Also, yes, it is possible to change the language strings in Language customisation. Documentation on how to do that is here: https://docs.moodle.org/32/en/Language_customisation Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you again! Unfortunately, it seems that Moodlecloud (which I'm testing these days) does not support language customization. Enrique

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: I just tried changing the custom login instructions for email based self registration on my moodlecloud site and I did see the change:

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Maybe it works for some strings but not all? I changed the "Course request" string to "Class request". The change still shows in the language pack editor, but does not show in the interface. mike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes - I just found that too.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Yes, I think it shows in the editor but not in the front page. This seems to be a serios limitation of Moodlecloud. Thank you for your contribution. Enrique

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: How do you do that?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Felipe - see Email-based self-registration (in response to your private message).

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: It works Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Enrique, You are correct. Support for customised language strings is limited on MoodleCloud. Â This is to ensure optimal performance for all MoodleCloud sites. Â So while you are able to make the changes to the language pack editor, the change may not appear on your MoodleCloud site. Access to the editor is allowed as there are some customisations that will work. Unfortunately, there is no definitive list for the customisations that will work across the many language packs. Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Chris and Mary, I think this is an issue HQ should address. It should either work fully or be turned off until it can be. Or at the very least have some warning. Since an important part of Moodlecloud's mission it to allow people to try out Moodle, for every person like Enrique who reports the issue, many people will just think it is the way Moodle works, never look into the issue, and so get a bad impression of Moodle as buggy and unreliable. And language customisation is one of those features where Moodle really stands out, it is done so well. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Randy, Thanks for the feedback and suggestions. MoodleCloud's aim is to provide as many standard Moodle features as possible. Sometimes we disable a feature to ensure the overall Moodle experience is a good one for everyone on the service. I agree language customisation is a great feature in Moodle and we will continue strive to find a way to implement it on MoodleCloud without impacting on site performance. Â In the meantime, we will implement a warning message as you suggest to ensure it is clear to users that the feature isn't supported. Thanks Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Customization
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks, Chris. I think a warning would be good thing. People will understand they are working a environment that's more controlled that if they had Moodle themselves. As long as that's clear, it will work. For instance, with the various admin setting config presets, which are clearly marked, I can easily explain to potential Moodlers what that means and why. Randy

ResponsesInList.Title: Using Google Drive to save file space on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, I've been tinkering with Google Drive as a repository on my Moodlecloud site and it's all set up and working as far as I can see. I can add files from Google Drive to Moodlecloud directly using the filepicker. What I would like to be able to do is to add them without the files being added to the file storage limit. I appreciate that I could just create a shareable link on Google Drive and copy/paste that into the Moodlecloud site but this seems to defeat the advantage of using GDrive as a repository. Is there something simple that I've missed - I thought it might be in the Internal/External/Internal and External options in the Repository settings but this seems to make no difference. cheers Colin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Google Drive to save file space on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Colin, Using the repository system should indeed use the file directly from google drive and not count in your quota, provided the setup is done to use all "external" options, as you pointed out. Moodle does however save the file locally as draft, which gets removed later (4 days in the current Moodle version, iirc), which could explain the quota change you see. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Google Drive to save file space on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Mathieu, I tried these things and left it a week but the files are still being counted in our Moodlecloud storage. Does anyone have any other suggestions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Google Drive to save file space on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Colin, I've been away for a while - I'm sorry to see this didn't work as expected. Can you confirm that (under "/admin/tool/oauth2/issuers.php") there is a "System account connected" for the google drive entry?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Google Drive to save file space on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Matthieu, Could you point me to the documentation for creating a Google Drive entry (as you state above). I'm a few steps behind you I think but want to achieve the same thing Colin is doing. Your help is really appreciated. Louis

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Using Google Drive to save file space on Moodlecloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Louis, The documentation is at https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/Google_Drive_repository and the first step is to do the OAuth2 setup in your Google account, as explained on https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/OAuth_2_Google_service I suggest your read both pages completely before you get started. Make sure to connect a "System account" (on the OAuth2 services page in Moodle). As explained on the "Google Drive repository" page (linked above), you should use a dedicated account for this purpose (this is the account that will keep a copy of your files on google drive). Depending if you are using an enterprise (vs personal) Google account, the screenshots might be different from what you get on the site, but the process is the same. Once this is all done, you may want to enable the Google auth, by following the documentation on https://docs.moodle.org/33/en/OAuth_2_authentication Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Difference between Moodlecloud and Download
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello I am new to moodle, I am reading articles but as there are so many I'm getting a bit lost. can anyone to me what is the difference between installing the free moodle on desk top or using a moodlecloud account ? Thank you

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Difference between Moodlecloud and Download
ResponsesInList.Text: In the simplest terms: if you install free Moodle on your desktop you can't easily run courses for students on it because Â it is just on your desktop and not on the internet. (Some people will try to tell Â you that you can, but it's very complex) People do this to test Moodle. MoodleCloud is a service offered by the people who make Moodle and they (we) set up a Moodle site online for you so you don't have to do the technical stuff and can just get on with teaching your class. There are longer answers and more details Â but hopefully that helps. Also - I see you are currently in our Learn Moodle MOOC. You could get yourself a MoodleCloud site to try restoring your practice course, if you wanted to.
