ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kate, The free site retention policy is there to ensure we can continue to provide free and low cost Moodle hosting options for all. Â We do send an email to the admin of your account well before the removal. If your site is not going to be used for a period of time, you can choose to upgrade to one of the plans where the policy does not apply. I can see how this is frustrating for you when you lose your site. Maybe the email got stuck in a spam folder. If you would like to continue with MoodleCloud, email support@moodlecloud.com with your site details and we'll see what we can do with your site. Thanks Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Recovering a "lost" attempt on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello everyone, I'm hosting a Moodle course using the Moodlecloud basic plan. Last week, one of my students did a quiz attempt but, somehow, it got lost - I think she didn't submit it, but I'm not sure. The problem is: it's like it never happened. She can't continue the quiz and there's no memory of her attempt. However, I can find it in the logs. When I click it, it shows: "Can not find data record in database table quiz_attempts" Is there any way I can access the attempts table on MoodleCloud? Thanks!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recovering a "lost" attempt on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Davi, This error is not specific to MoodleCloud and the folks in the quiz forum might be more helpful at explaining how this happens (and how to prevent it). It is not possible to access the sql tables of a MoodleCloud site, but if you contact us from the MoodleCloud portal (we would then know which site is yours...) we might be able to help. I agree with you that she might have not submitted her attempt and unfortunately in this case, looking at the database would not recover anything. Mathieu

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recovering a "lost" attempt on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: There are only two ways this can happen: A teacher goes and manually deletes the attempt using the quiz reports. (Check the logs.) The permissions are set up wrong, so the student has the teacher's permission to preview the quiz instead of attempt it (Use Quiz administration -> Check permissions and look for mod/quiz:preview.)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recovering a "lost" attempt on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks for the reply, Tim! That makes sense: this particular student was also acting as my assistant, so she had administrator privileges. It's very possible that she just previewed the test and thought she was making a real attempt. In this case, is there any way to get her answers back? Thanks again!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Recovering a "lost" attempt on MoodleCloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry, no. (Vote for MDL-54875 .)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Transferring ownership (especially the phone number)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Kathleen Thanks for explaining the situation further and highlighting the difficulties in transferring a site. Free sites do require the phone number to be verified so its not possible to change the mobile number on an Free site account. Paid plan sites can be validated via email so the phone number becomes less important to the verification process and ongoing account ownership. Currently we do not offer the ability to change your phone number, which I can see causes a problem for you when trying to transfer ownership once upgraded or you move on from an organisation.Â The MoodleCloud team are investigating the best way to handle this scenario. In the meantime I've opened a support ticket for you so so we can go through specific details of your account and sites to get this all sorted out. Thanks Chris

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: LDAP on MoodleCloud

ResponsesInList.Text: To add an administrator, click the Site administration link, and then from the Users tab, in the Permissions area, you will see a link Site adminstrators. You add them there.

ResponsesInList.Title: Automated backup Enabled setting is not saved
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hello, We are using the Moodle for School/Mini package and when
trying to setup the automated backup to Enabled, after saving the setting remains
Disabled. It is very important for us to back up our data
automatically, so Iâ€™ll appreciate your quick response and help with this issue. Thanks in advance

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automated backup Enabled setting is not saved
ResponsesInList.Text: HiÂ Jacki, We disabled automated scheduled backups due to everyone using it going over their site quota. MoodleCloud packages have a relatively low disk quota, and backups eat into this extremely quickly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automated backup Enabled setting is not saved
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Jordan, This is very frustrating... It doesn't make sense to provide this package without the ability to backup the data and without documenting this limitation clearly! I would be willing to pay more to have a larger quota and would expect Moodle to provide this option and manage the quota letting the user know when the usage is close to the limit and decide whether to buy more space or clean some old data. As the above is impossible, I would like to cancel the 1 year package I paid for and get a refund, after I will manually backup the work I have already made. May I notify you when I want to do that? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Automated backup Enabled setting is not saved
ResponsesInList.Text: You can backup your data at any time by doing a manual course backup, we have not stopped users from doing this. If your site has 200mb of quota and you have a 100mb course, 1 backup of this course will put you close to your quota limit. If you had automatic backups on then you would be over quota after 2 automated backups and this is exactly what was happening to our users which prompted us to disable automatic backups. At this time we are not able to offer additional storage space in our plans. Our system already notifies you when you are close to or over your quota limit. Refunds are considered on a case by case basis (as per our terms you agreed to), and you should submit a ticket via the Support tab in your MoodleCloud Portal in order to get this process started.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Video Embed

 If you find it then remove it. Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Become a host

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Become a host
ResponsesInList.Text:
Hi Jessica, We have a lot of plugins already installed. Moodle for Free sites are designed to be easy to use, and come with the standard MoodleCloud theme More. Your site is preconfigured with the plugins that are made
available in the standard Moodle version. Also included is an integrated
the open source web conferencing System, BigBlueButton . Starter sites include the same plugins as Moodle for Free sites and
also come with the popular and very useful Custom Certificate plugin
allowing you to reward students with certificates through your courses. Moodle for School sites come with the most popular and Moodle
plugins, that will cover the needs of most Educators. The current list
of provided plugins is available at https://moodle.com/cloud/school .
Keep an eye on the list as it will grow, and we always appreciate
feedback and suggestions, so let us know if you think a certain plugin
would benefit Moodle for School users. If you require specific plugins for your Moodle site, contact one of our Moodle Partners to discuss your custom hosting needs. Please take a look at our FAQs for more information - https://moodle.com/cloud/faq/ Many thanks.

ResponsesInList.Title: Clone/copy a Moodle cloud server to my own location?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hey there. I currently have a Moodlecloud server , and I would like to have a perfectly identical copy on my home server for things like experimentation without messing up the important one, having an alternative location, etc. How do I accomplish this? Thanks in advance! GSpencer

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Clone/copy a Moodle cloud server to my own location?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, First a few things you should know - MoodleCloud extends core Moodle to provide things like BigBlueButton, a new theme and some other optimisations (caching etc) so you wont have a 100% exact mirror but it will be close enough. You can download Moodle from https://download.moodle.org/ You can perform a Site Export of your MoodleCloud site from the Portal by visiting https://moodlecloud.com and logging in using your site name and admin password, then going to Tools -> Export my site. You can restore your site export to the database on your home server and with a few minor tweaks of the provided config.php you will be up and running in no time. If you need help along the way be sure to check https://docs.moodle.org as we cannot provide support for sites hosted off the MoodleCloud platform.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Clone/copy a Moodle cloud server to my own location?
ResponsesInList.Text: Great, I expected as much. Although I'm curious what you mean by 'a few minor tweaks of the provided config.php'. Is it only updating the url of the new server, or something more involved? GS

ResponsesInList.Title: Forum policy - PLEASE READ before posting
ResponsesInList.Text: This forum is for community discussion about MoodleCloud. MoodleCloud is our own hosting platform, designed and run by Moodle HQ, the people who make Moodle. Â MoodleCloud provides a super simple way to get up and running with the latest Moodle version in minutes. MoodleCloud hosting is inexpensive because we don't include a lot of support. If you need assistance with setup and configuration of your site, visit the Moodle community and Moodle documentation for lots of helpful information on any Moodle topic. Â There is a handy link in the footer on each Moodle page to take you to the appropriate Moodle documentation for that area of Moodle. To this point, we have developed this policy for posting to this forum. Â Posts which violate this policy may be edited, moved to a more appropriate forum or deleted at the discretion of our forum moderators. If you have a question about MoodleCloud Ensure you have explored our dedicated FAQ page to see if your question already has an answer. Is your question a Moodle question? Does the question start with "In Moodle, how do I..." Â If so, then please search for the appropriate forum for the post. This will provide a better experience for all and the answer may already be provided. If you think it may be an issue or bug in MoodleCloud and you can verify your issue does not happen on the same version of Moodle outside of MoodleCloud, please open a bug over at https://tracker.moodle.org under the CLOUD project. Etiquette Discussion tone should be kept polite and focused on facts. Our public forums must not be used for defamation or flaming. Don't forget to talk about good experiences as well as the bad! Your identity Fake identities created on Moodle.org for the purpose of criticism will not be tolerated, and those accounts may be closed. Text taken from the Moodle.org site policy .

ResponsesInList.Title: Removing a participant from Moodlecloud site

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Removing a participant from Moodlecloud site
ResponsesInList.Text: You can both un-enrol a participant from a course (while the user keeps access to the site) and delete a user from the site (thus freeing some space in your allocated 50 users quota). To delete a user, you go to Site Administration -> Users ->Â Browse list of users, from there you can click on the 'X' at the right end of the line of the user you wish to delete.

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle Cloud https won't connect with an LTI with http location
ResponsesInList.Text: I'm attempting to add an External Tool but it's failing to load (blank screen). Â I consulted an IT professional and he stated that as Moodle Cloud is https, and the External Tool I'm trying to add is http, Moodle Cloud will reject the request. The host providing me with the LTI tool and shared secret are http only. I'm also assuming Moodle Cloud cannot and will not deactivate https either... Is there anyway where I can get around this to have both LMS' connect to one another?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle Cloud https won't connect with an LTI with http location
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Natalie, sorry that you are encountering some troubles. The IT professional you consulted with is correct, http LTI tools can't be used on an https moodle instance. (but the reverse case would work: https tools can be used on http moodle instances, but I digress) You are correct, moodle cloud doesn't offer an option to disable SSL/https. Even if it did, you would not want to because of the security risk that would pose to your site.Â Basically, https on your cloud instance ensures that all content is encrypted and verifiably from your site. But if an http tool is used on that site, the content from that tool would not be encrypted, which would allow attackers to gain access to information about your users passed over LTI requests. So all modern browsers will not allow http content (such as LTI) on an https site. So your best option is to contact the provider of your tool and ask them to start using SSL on their site so you can use it via https. This is in their best interests as well as it protects all their clients' data. SSL certificates are cheap these days, and the extra processing power required is not really a problem. If you haven't already you might want to just double check that the tool is definitely not already working when you use https instead. If the tool provider really refuses to start using SSL, your do have the option is create a proxy server on top of their tool which allows you to send the LTI requests via https and then forward them to the original tool. But I would recommend leaving that as your last option

ResponsesInList.Title: Moodle vs Moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi all, 1- what is the main differences between Moodle and Moodle cloud ? 2- Can we use Moodle cloud in any university as MOOC in stead of normal Moodle? 3- What is the additional features in Moodle cloud that is can not found or solve the problems found in Moodle? Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle vs Moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: 1 Moodle cloud is mainly for testing Moodle out rather than real use for anything more than small courses IMHO . It is very restricted (as it probably should be to minimise support issues and ensure stability). 2 Given the limitations, could be an issue depending on the variables of the intended MOOC. 3 None, quite possibly the opposite - the restrictions on Moodle cloud means you can't use plugins etc. to fill a gap in your requirements.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Moodle vs Moodle cloud
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, It's worth pointing out here that MoodleCloud is not just used for testing and is used for real use in production Moodle installations. The free site does come with restrictions, however you can upgrade to a paid site on a larger plan which offers more file space, more users etc... See more: https://moodlecloud.com/en/ Thanks.
